moves.2. Nf3 d6 3. h3: unknown variation to me. Not sure I see the point for this move.
moves.5... e5: I felt comfortable with this, though d6 seems weak: white is so closed, that black has to take advantage of it and move on
moves.6. Bc2: bishop has already 2 moves and does not seem to be clearly pointing something interesting.
moves.6... Be7 7. O-O O-O: well, yes, both bishops and the queen are pointing to king side, but with so much obstacles, and pointing to h6 and 7, is it really pointing?
moves.10. Bb3: probably discovering his bishop is worthless; tries to exchange with advantage by queen development. I won't help
moves.10... Qd7: actually my idea was to take back with f7 if ever needed, to open f column.
moves.11... b5: well, let's go: white seems not to have any  plan. Mine was to take advantage of my own progression.
moves.12. Bc2: getting back home? Is White some kind of a hedgehog?
moves.12... a5: f won't open => let's open a-b-c
moves.14. Nh2: Ah, finally, proposing an opening on f4?
moves.15... f5: then I open f-column; i also have all my officers ready to point there, except Nc6
moves.17. Bd2 Rf6: preparing Rg6 or, if Nh4, then g5. I calculated Bxh3 was prematurate
moves.18. Qe2: i guess Black saw a potential Nxe5 dxe and Qxh5
moves.18... g6: with the idea to get back to Ng7, then g5, g4
moves.19. g4: but it won't be necessary: white offers me the opening.
moves.20. Ng4: at least gains one more pawn
moves.20... Bxg4 21. hxg4 Qxg4 22. Bd1: surprise, but not a bad one: this really underestimates the next move.
moves.23... Rf7: i considered Rxf3, but it lead to equalizing, without profit.
moves.24... Bh4+: then if Kf1, Ng3+ Rxg3 Qxg3 is the best solution, but...
